text_image_relationship.layout_style: Eight medallion scenes arranged in four horizontal rows of two columns occupy the central field, flanked on left and right by narrow columns of text in Latin. A narrow decorative border runs along top and bottom. The roundels form a regular grid, creating a strong visual hierarchy of images over text. Captions in the margins directly reference adjacent scenes.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with decorative flourishes, extensive use of abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for backgrounds and divine figures, establishing immediate hierarchical significance. Ultramarine and azurite blues denote sacred robes (especially Christ’s mantle), while vermillion and minium red emphasize dramatic garments and blood. Verdigris green appears in vegetal motifs in borders. Layered application of white highlights creates volume in flesh tones. Alternating red and blue mantles form a color rhythm across the grid. Overall, original colors remain bright with minimal oxidation of lead white.

features: Uniform two-column by four-row arrangement of roundels
Small square portrait busts separating medallions
Central gold quatrefoil junctions linking scenes
Consistent circular framing of narrative episodes
Symmetrical balance of left and right imagery

decorative_elements: Gold quatrefoil frames around each medallion
Micro-architectural arches and pinnacles between roundels
Small square bust portraits of prophets or saints
Diapered red and white patterned background in interstices
Blue bead-pattern border at top and bottom

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill pen outlines in dark brown ink with controlled variation of stroke weight
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat washes of pigment with minimal hatching, punctuated by white highlights for volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; depth implied by overlapping figures and frames

scene_relationships.subject: Arrest of Christ in Gethsemane
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to Christ before the High Priest through the betrayal narrative

Red cloak of soldier echoes red mantle in next scene
Gestural lines of raised swords point toward adjacent frame

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Precedes the Scourging by highlighting judicial condemnation

Architectural arch motif spans both medallions

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to the Institution of the Eucharist as a contrasting sacred moment

White tunics recur in both roundels

scene_relationships.subject: Institution of the Eucharist
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Foreshadows Christ’s judgment by contrasting sacrament with suffering
visual_connections: Table drapery pattern continues into next medallion’s floor
Haloed heads repeat circular motif

scene_relationships.subject: Mocking of Christ by Soldiers
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to Christ before Pilate by moving from mob violence to official trial
visual_connections: Soldiers’ red mantles echo brightness in trial scene
Stone floor pattern continues
Repetitive triangular composition of figures

scene_relationships.subject: Christ before Pilate
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Precedes the Entry into Jerusalem by recalling political authority wielded over Christ
visual_connections: Pilate’s purple garment matches donkey-rider’s cloak later
Raised hands gesture repeats in entry scene

scene_relationships.subject: Triumphal Entry into Jerusalem
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to the Ascension as the narrative moves from earthly ministry to glorification
visual_connections: Palm branches motif reappears in ascension scene
Blue and red garments alternate
Diagonal composition of donkey and figures continues

scene_relationships.subject: Ascension of Christ
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Concludes the cycle as the upward gesture contrasts with entry and suffering
visual_connections: Heavenly gesture of ascending hands echoes arrest scene’s raised arms
Gold background unifies all scenes
Circular halos reinforce divine continuity

visual_continuity: Uniform blue and red color alternation in figures’ mantles
Small square bust portraits appear between all medallions
Repeating diaper pattern in interstitial spaces

content_theme.scene_description: Primary Scene Analysis (Scene 1, Arrest of Christ): Eight figures occupy the roundel: Christ at center stands serenely, haloed, in a blue tunic edged with gold. Four armed soldiers surround him, two on each side, clad in red mantles over chainmail and carrying spears and swords. Judas Iscariot, distinguished by a dark green hood and lighter tunic, grasps Christ’s wrist. A high priest in white headcover and purple cloak stands behind, gesturing condemnation. Ground is tiled in lead white and vermillion squares. Christ’s right hand is raised in a blessing gesture; his left rests on a scroll. The figures are overlapped to suggest depth, with the soldiers in the foreground. Christ is slightly larger, indicating his spiritual primacy. The soles of soldiers’ boots and the hem of Christ’s tunic are detailed with white highlights, creating modest volume. Secondary Elements: Small square busts of prophets at the roundel’s corners echo the narrative; decorative gold quatrefoil junctions link to adjacent scenes; the diapered red background fills negative space. Symbolic Components: Judas’s green hood signals betrayal; Christ’s halo and book scroll are theological attributes; soldiers’ swords represent violent injustice. Compositional Focus: Christ’s calm posture anchors the viewer’s eye; the dynamic diagonal of raised spears provides tension; visual weight is balanced between the left and right soldiers. Visual-Textual Relationships: Text in the left margin describes the betrayal and is aligned with Christ’s figure, reinforcing the narrative. The initial letter at the margin shares the same gold and blue palette as the roundel, visually linking text and image. Caption lines are justified to the edges of the medallion, creating a deliberate correspondence between written and pictorial elements.

religious: Christ with nimbus and blue tunic

natural: Olive tree branches suggested behind soldiers

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, smooth surface with visible hair follicle pattern on flesh side; regular quaternion gathering, margins ca. 3 cm wide
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight cockling at folio edges; minor flaking of red in soldier’s mantles; modern conservation stabilization noted
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf creating slight relief
Confident underdrawing visible under UV light
Regular ruling pattern in plummet delineates text and image fields

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Monastic community in a cathedral school

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-13th-century Passion cycle exemplifies the evolving moralized Bible tradition produced in Parisian workshops. The rigorous Gothic textura quadrata script and lavish burnished gold backgrounds reflect a high-status commission, likely for a cathedral school’s teaching collection. The grid of eight roundels interspersed with prophetic busts and surrounded by theological glosses indicates its dual purpose as both visual aide-mémoire and exegetical tool. Stylistically, the manuscript shows the influence of the English Channel School in its delicate linear underdrawing and refined facial types, while its vibrant palette—ultramarine, vermillion, and gilding—demonstrates Parisian access to luxury pigments. The narrative composition combines grid-like order with hierarchical scaling: Christ is consistently central and slightly larger, visually reinforcing his theological primacy. Iconographically, the sequence links Old Testament prophecy (bust portraits) to New Testament fulfillment (Passion events), underscoring medieval typological interpretation. Politically, the portrayal of Pilate’s judicial acts alongside sacramental imagery subtly parallels contemporary ecclesiastical authority over secular power. Compared to contemporaneous works such as the Psalter of Blanche of Castile, this cycle is more didactic in layout, integrating glosses and small-scale portraits. While it adheres to traditional iconographic programs, the manuscript demonstrates innovation in its tight integration of text and image, reflecting a collaborative atelier practice with multiple hands contributing to script, painting, and gilding.
